content_1: .  In the Guangdong province of China, the Guangdong Provincial Agriculture Department is investigating a duck market in the city of Guangzhou after a two-year old boy from Hong Kong visited the market in mid-May and was confirmed to have H5N1 on June 5th.  The Guangzhou Agriculture and Animal Husbandry Department has launched an inspection of the Jiangnandong Market, and according to the Municipal Animal Epidemic Disease Control and Prevention Center, one duck, out of 40 samples, has tested positive for the H5N1 virus.  As of Tuesday, no other confirmed reports of human infection have been reported.
content_2: .  A new H5N1 avian flu virus (clade 2.3.2.1c) is spreading rapidly across northern and central Vietnam.  As of September 6, 2012, seven provinces have bird flu epidemics and more than 180,000 poultry have been culled.  The source of these outbreaks is inconclusive, although the vice president of the Vietnam Animal Husbandry Agency, Nguyen Thanh Son, believes chickens illegally imported from China were the source of the virus.  Control measures applied include quarantine, movement control, disinfection, and strict regulation of the import of breeding chickens from China; while control measures yet to be applied include screening and zoning to monitor any possible future outbreaks and vaccination in response to the outbreaks.  Experts say that the new avian flu virus developed in July and spread to the northern and central regions of Vietnam in August.  The Central Veterinary Diagnosis Center will start testing the current vaccine against the new virus within the next couple of days.
